author: R Vimal Kumar
text:
Encouraged by the recent verdict from Supreme Court, the Tirupur knitwear exporters, who are waging a legal battle against various banks in the alleged derivatives scam, have sought more details from Reserve Bank of India regarding the scam.

The Supreme Court had ordered the RBI not to withhold any information sought by the exporters regarding the scam. Raja Shanmugam, a Tirupur-based exporter and president of Forex Derivatives Consumer Forum formed of aggrieved exporters who lost Rs 300 crore after buying forex derivatives sold by the banks to hedge currency fluctuations during 2007-08 fiscal, had filed the case.

Though RBI, in one of the affidavits filed before Orissa High Court, stated that “total mark to market losses on account of currency derivatives is to the tune of more than Rs. 31,719 crore,” it refused to provide details of bank-wise losses sought by Mr. Shanmugam.

At the same time, RBI had imposed fines on 19 banks for selling ‘unsuitable derivative products’ to the exporters.

In the new petition, the exporters had sought two crucial data apart from the bank-wise losses statement, which would be critical for their legal battle against the banks.

“We have sought copies of Annual Financial Inspection Reports and concurrent audit reports for the period between April 1, 2007, and March 31, 2015, on the foreign currency derivative contracts sold by the said 19 banks. The other important detail is regarding the responses received from the banks to the RBI’s show cause notice which eventually forced RBI to impose fines on them,” said S. Dhananjayan, technical advisor to the forum.

The Supreme Court ordered the RBI not to withhold any information sought by the exporters
title: Derivatives scam: more details sought
